qas.question: Where were records made with raised label areas?
Are longer recordings, as found in operas, made for use with auto-changing systems?

answers.text: interleaved across several 10-inch or 12-inch discs for use with auto-changing mechanisms

qas.question: Do grooves on records touch when stacked?

answers.text: allowing records to be stacked onto each other without the delicate grooves coming into contact

qas.question: Do records touch when in auto changers?

answers.text: Auto-changers included a mechanism to support a stack

context: When auto-changing turntables were commonplace, records were typically pressed with a raised (or ridged) outer edge and a raised label area, <a2_0>allowing records to be stacked onto each other without the delicate grooves coming into contact<a2_0/>, <a0_0>reducing the risk of damage<a0_0/>. <a3_0>Auto-changers included a mechanism to support a stack<a3_0/> of several records above the turntable itself, dropping them one at a time onto the active turntable to be played in order. Many longer sound recordings, such as complete operas, were <a1_0>interleaved across several 10-inch or 12-inch discs for use with auto-changing mechanisms<a1_0/>, so that the first disk of a three-disk recording would carry sides 1 and 6 of the program, while the second disk would carry sides 2 and 5, and the third, sides 3 and 4, allowing sides 1, 2, and 3 to be played automatically; then the whole stack reversed to play sides 4, 5, and 6.
